passages.text: August 29,2025 04:00 AM GMT
WHAT'S CHANGEDRolls-Royce Holdings PLC (RR.L)FromPrice Target900p

We address the key debates on current valuation metrics and potential fair value, alongside a material upgrade to our estimates. We sit mid- to- high single digit ahead of cons profit and FCF, and raise our PT to GBP1,275. We think there is more to go, with upside risk to estimates and valuation metrics.

Strong share price performance, underpinned by end market growth and management's turnaround, brings with it a number of valuation debates. We think FCF should be the primary metric for appraising Rolls, as it best captures the value creation from the LTSA business model. Nonetheless, we continue to take a blended view, applying a 50:50 mix of SOTP and DCF, in- line with our treatment across our A&D coverage. We make no adjustment in our valuation for the net LTSA balance, but acknowledge there is a spectrum of views on its treatment. Rolls trades at a FCF yield discount to Safran. We think if the turnaround continues to play out as expected, it deserves a premium.

Rolls Has Come a Long Way- From an emergency rights issue and asset fire sale during the height of the pandemic, we now think the group is on track to generate over £5bn of FCF in 2028, with a net cash balance of almost £13bn (14% current market cap) that- same year. This impressive recovery story, underpinned by growth in key end markets and turbocharged by a multi- year transformation strategy under current management, has driven \(>10x\) in the shares from the 2020 avg. But this success has also brought with it a number of key debates on valuation - regarding both current metrics, as well as how best to assess potential fair value.

FCF vs Profit - The Relative Merits: In short, we think FCF should be the primary valuation metric for Rolls, as it better captures the value creation from the group's long- term service agreement (LTSA) business model. Profit metrics remain relevant, but are more 'backward looking' in nature for the group's core Civil engine division, in that an engine shop visit today reflects prior activity. This discrepancy between FCF and profit is less pronounced at peers GE Aerospace and Safran, given a significantly lower proportion of their engines are under LTSAs, resulting in a higher

Morgan Stanley does and seeks to do business with companies covered in Morgan Stanley Research. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of Morgan Stanley Research. Investors should consider Morgan Stanley Research as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

Morgan Stanley & Co. International plc is a corporate broker to Rolls- Royce Holdings PLC.

relative contribution from spare parts, which better reflect current demand, pricing, and scope dynamics. We continue to take a blended view, applying a 50:50 mix of sum- of- the- parts (EV/EBIT and PE) and DCF, in- line with our treatment across our A&D coverage. Naturally, our DCF valuation is higher than our SOTP output.

FCF vs Profit - The Discrepancy in Practice: Our new Rolls forecasts assume a FCF conversion ratio (to adj. net income) of \(130\%\) on average 2025- 30. This compares to GE Aerospace consensus at \(107\%\) (guidance \(\sim 100\%\) through 2028) and Safran consensus at \(99\%\) . This higher relative FCF generation, driven by LTSAs, means there is a wide discrepancy between FCF and profit valuation metrics – Rolls trades on an MSe FCF yield of \(5.2\%\) in 2027, a discount to Safran on \(4.0\%\) and GE Aerospace on \(3.0\%\) . However, Rolls trades on an MSe 2027 EV/EBIT of \(18x\) and P/E of \(27x\) , a premium to Safran on \(17x / 24x\) , albeit still at a discount to GE on \(27x / 34x\) .

The Age Old Debate - How to Treat Net LTSA Balance Growth: We find there is a spectrum of investor views on how to treat the net LTSA balance, which is essentially the engine cash receipts not offset by LTSA revenues (shop visits). Under accounting standards, this cash is treated as deferred revenue. But given it is essentially a downpayment tied to a future obligation (shop visits), some investors take different approaches: (i) "Cash Is Cash" - the most common approach, with no specific adjustments for LTSA, in line with the treatment of downpayments at other companies in the sector e.g. Airbus. We take this approach; (ii) Discount - given the LTSA balance is future revenue, there is both a future cost and profit element. Some investors therefore only include the future profit element (some even apply tax), dependent on LTSA margin assumptions (typically \(\sim 50\%\) ); (iii) Remove - some investors choose to conservatively remove the net LTSA balance completely from their FCF calculations. For context, management has guided to the net LTSA balance growth being in the £0.8- 1.2bn range medium term (lower- end nearer term, upper- end medium term). At the £1bn guidance midpoint, this would remove \(\sim 24\%\) of our cumulative £16.9bn of FCF 2025- 28.

Our View - We Think Rolls Ultimately Deserves to Trade at a Premium to Safran: We continue to think Rolls is on track to achieve one of the greatest turnarounds in UK corporate history, resulting in a group with four industry- leading businesses in diverse and growing end markets. Safran is rightly the highest quality stock in the European aerospace sector today, and has been for some time. The quality of its Propulsion division is not be understated, underpinned by its \(50\%\) share in CFM International. But the group has an underperforming Interiors business where it has allocated considerable levels of capital and management bandwidth over the years. Hence we think there is justification for Rolls to eventually trade at a FCF yield premium to Safran if the turnaround continues to play out as expected.

We Raise Our PT to GBp1,275: Our new price target implies a \(4.3\%\) yield for 2027, a marginal discount to Safran (3.9%). This is driven by a mix of (i) higher forecasts (more below); (ii) higher multiples in our SOTP - we raise our Civil multiples to 22.5x EV/EBIT (from 18x) and 31x P/E (from 23x) for 2027 to reflect higher growth and margins; (iii) a marginally higher value for SMR - to £732m, in- line with Rolls' fair value assumption, up from £500m previously; and (iv) higher pre- discount FCF estimates in our DCF to more closely reflect actual forecasts.

**Is There More Upside Potential? Our Bull Case Suggests70% Upside from Here** **(~GBp1,800):** We see further potential upside to both estimates and valuation metrics as transformation actions progressively benefited Our Bull case assumes higher growth across the group (13% CAGR 21%,+200bp vs our base case), as well as higher 2027 margins: (i) 23% for Civil, in-line with Safran Propulsion; (ii) 18% for Defence, +200bp vs MSe and the top-end management's guidance range; and (iii) 19% for Power Systems, broadly in-line with peer Cummins Power Systems.

Applying 23x EV/EBIT and 34x P/E, a premium to Safran but discount to GE, blended with our bull case DCF PT, results in an implied valuation of GBp1,797. This includes no additional value creation in SMR, where we note CEO Tufan Erginbilgic recently commented that he believes SMR could help Rolls become the largest company in the UK. Based on the current FTSE100 constituents, this would require a market cap of at least £185bn (up >100% from here).

**Forecast Changes**: We make wholesale updates to our model, including (i) lower Civil OE revenues, driven by marginally lower engine deliveries, lower spare engine unit price assumptions, lower on-wing gross profit forecasts, and less favourable FX rates (see below); (ii) higher Civil Aftermarket revenues, profit and cash, driven by higher T&M, fewer SVs and update mix (reflecting time on wing initiatives), higher LTSA margin assumptions, offset by FX; (iii) modestly higher growth and margin in Defence; and (iv) higher growth and margin in Power Systems, reflecting higher growth in Power Gen and Governmental subsegments. Elsewhere, we lower our tax rate assumption for 2025 to 22.5% from 25%. We also reflect the deconsolidation of the SMR business. Our USD/GBP rate assumptions move to 144-134 2025-30, from 144-130.
Exhibit 1: Forecast changes - Rolls-Royce
Source: Morgan Stanley Research estimates
Beat, Raise, Rinse, Repeat
Key: Historical Stock Performance Current Stock Price Price Target

An ambitious yet credible transformation plan is under way, which seeks to make Rolls a more competitive, profitable and cash- generative business. New medium- term (2028) financial targets have been set; we are confident that the group can surpass these.

The group is benefitting from growth in all key end markets - international air traffic, defence spending, and data centres. This is compounded by cost, pricing, and cultural actions as part of the transformation plan. Leverage is falling, supporting Rolls' return to investment grade credit rating status and a reinstatement of the dividend and launch of a buyback (at FY24). We see the potential for higher shareholder returns in the future.
Source: Refinitiv, Morgan Stanley Research

The probabilities of our Bull, Base, and Bear case scenarios playing out were estimated with implied volatility data from the options market as of 28 Aug 2025. All figures are approximate risk- neutral probabilities of the stock reaching beyond the scenario price in either three- months' or one- years' time. View explanation of Options Probabilities methodology here
- Group revenue CAGR (3-year 2024-27) of 13% driven by above-trend EFH growth and shop visit volumes (Civil Aerospace CAGR 15%), and strong execution of the backlog in Defence and Power Systems.
- Group EBIT margin expansion of 620bp to 20.0% in 2027, with Civil Aerospace 23% (vs 2.5% in 2022), Defence 18%, and Power Systems 19%.
- Multiples-based approach applies 23x to estimated 2027 EBIT and 34x to 2027 EPS.

- Group revenue CAGR (3-year 2024-27) of 11% driven by the core Civil Aerospace division (13% CAGR), including large engine EFH rising to 110% of 2019 levels in 2025 and 131% in 2028, and 1,297 shop visits in 2028.
- Group EBIT margin expansion of 360bp to 17.4% in 2027, with Civil Aerospace reaching 20.4%, Defence 16.1%, and Power Systems 16.9%.
- Multiples-based approach applies 21x to estimated 2027 EBIT and 27x to 2027 EPS.

- Group revenue CAGR (3-year 2024-27) of only 9%, driven by lower EFH and shop visit growth due to economic headwinds and a material increase in retirements, as well as OE delays due to persistent supply chain weakness.
- Group EBIT margin expands only 70bp to 14.5% in 2027, due primarily to higher shop visit costs.
- Multiples-based approach applies 15x to estimated 2027 EBIT and 19x to 2027 EPS.

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Equal-weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Not-Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In-Line (I): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Cautious (C): The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia -relevant MSCI country index or MSCI ac Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
